sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Do ye smell nothing?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Not I sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: The carrion of knaves is very strong in my nostrils.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
We came to admire, and find fame was a niggard
Which we thought prodigal in our report
Before we saw you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Tush sir, this Courtship is old.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
I will fight for thee sweet wench,
This is my tongue and woes for me?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Good man of War,
Hands off; if you take me it must be by siege,
Not by an onset; and for your valour, I
Think that I have deserved few enemies,
And therefore need it not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Thou needst nothing sweet Lady, but an obsequious
husband, and where wilt thou find him, if not
in the City we are true Moscovits to our Wives, and are
never better pleased, than when they use us as slaves,
bridle and saddle us; have me, thou shalt command all
my wealth as thine own, thou shalt sit like a Queen in
my ware house; And my factors at the return with my
ships shall pay thee tribute of all the rarities of the earth;
thou shalt wear gold, feed on delicates, the first peascods-strawberries,
grapes, cherries shall -

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Be mine; I apprehend what you would say,
Those dainties which the City pays so dear for,
The Country yields for nothing, and as early;
And credit me your far fetched viands please not
My appetite better than those that are near hand.
Then for your promised service and subjection
To all my humours, when I am your wife,
Which as it seems is frequent in the City,
I cannot find what pleasure they receive
In using their fond husbands like their Maids;
But of this more hereafter; I accept
Your proffer kindly, and yours; my house stands open
To entertain you; take your pleasure in it,
And ease after your journey.

sp.speaker: La. Orl.
sp.p: Do you note the boldness of the fellows?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Alas Madam, a virgin must in this be like a lawyer,
And as he takes all fees, she must hear all suitors; the
One for gain, the other for her mirth; stay with the
Gentlemen, we will to the Orchards.

div2.stage: Exeunt Lamira, La. Orle. Veram. Charl.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: - what art thou?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
An honest man, though poor;
And look they like to monsters, are they so rare?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Rose from the dead.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Do you hear Monsieur Servitor, didst thou never
hear of one Montague a prodigal gull, that lives
about Paris?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
One that after the loss of his main estate in a
Law suit, bought an Office in the Court.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
And should have letters of Mart, to have the
Spanish treasure as it came from the Indies; were not
thou and he twins? put off thy hat, let me see thy forehead.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Though you take privilege to use your tongues,
I pray you hold your fingers,
It was your base cozenage made me as I am,
And were you some where else I would take off
This proud film from your eyes, that will not tell you,
Know I am Montague.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I will observe this better.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
And art thou he? I will do thee grace; give me
thy hand; I am glad thou hast taken so good a course;
serve God and please thy Mistress; if I prove to be thy Master
as I am very likely, I will do for thee.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Faith the fellow is well made for a serving-man,
and will no doubt carry a chine of Beef with good
grace.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
Prithee be careful of me in my chamber, I will
remember thee at my departure.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
All this I can endure under this roof,
And so much owe I her, whose now I am,
That no wrong shall incense me to molest
Her quiet house; while you continue here,
I will not be ashamed to do you service
More than to her, because such is her pleasure.
But you that have broke thrice, and fourteen times
Compounded for two shillings in the pound,
Know I dare kick you in your shop; do ye hear?
If ever I see Paris, though an army
Of musty Murrions, rusty brown bills and clubs,
Stand for your guard - I have heard of your tricks,
And you that smell of Amber at my charge,
And triumph in your cheat; well I may live
To meet thee, be it among a troop of such
That are upon the fair face of the Court
Like running ulcers, and before thy whore
Trample upon thee.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
This a language for a livery? take heed, I am
a Captain.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
A Cox-comb are you not? that thou and I
To give proof, which of us dares most, were now
In midst of a rough Sea, upon a piece
Of a split ship, where only one might ride,
I would - but foolish anger makes me talk
Like a Player.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Indeed you act a part
Doth ill become you my servant; is this your
duty?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I crave your pardon, and will hereafter be more
circumspect.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
O the power of a Woman's tongue! it had
done more than we three with our swords durst undertake:
put a mad man to silence.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Why Sirrah these are none of your comrades
To drink with in the cellar; one of them
For aught you know may live to be your Master.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: There is some comfort yet.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Here is choice of three, a wealthy Merchant.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Hem, she is taken, she hath spied my good Calf,
And many Ladies choose their husbands by that.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
A Courtier that is in grace, a valiant Captain,
And are these mates for you? away be gone.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I humbly pray you will be pleased to pardon,
And to give satisfaction to you Madam.
(Although I break my heart) I will confess
That I have wronged them too, and make submission.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
No I will spare that; go bid the Cook haste
Supper.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
O brave Lady thou art worthy to have servants,
to be commandress of a Family, that knowest how to use
and govern it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
You shall have many Mistresses that will so
mistake as to take their horse keepers, and footmen instead
of their Husbands, thou art none of those.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
But she that can make distinction of men, and
knows when she hath gallants, and fellows of rank and
quality in her house -

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Gallants indeed, if it be the Gallants fashion
To triumph in the miseries of a man,
Of which they are the cause: one that transcends
(In spite of all that fortune hath, or can be done)
A million of such things as you, my doors
Stand open to receive all such as wear
The shape of Gentlemen, and my gentler nature
(I might say weaker) weighs not the expense
Of entertainment; think you I will forget yet
What is due unto myself? do not I know,
That you have dealt with poor Montague, but like
Needy Commanders, cheating Citizens,
And perjured Courtiers? I am much moved, else use not
To say so much, if you will bear yourselves
As fits such you would make me think you are,
You may stay; if not the way lies before you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: What think you of this Captain?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
That this is a bawdy house, with Pinnacles
and Turrets, in which this disguised Montague goes to
rut gratis, and that this is a landed panderess, and makes
her house a brothel for charity.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Come, that is no miracle; but from whence derive
you the supposition?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Observe but the circumstance; you all know
that in the height of Montagues prosperity, he did
affect and had his love returned by this Lady Orleans;
since her divorcement, and his decay of estate, it is
known, they have met not so much as his boy is
wanting; and that this can be anything else than a mere
plot for their night work, is above my imagination to
conceive.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Nay it carries probability, let us observe it
better, but yet with such caution as our prying be not
discovered: here is all things to be had without cost, and
therefore good staying here.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
Nay that is true, I would we might woe her
twenty years like Penelopes suitors; come Laverdine.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I follow instantly, yonder he is.

The thought of this Boy hath much cooled my affection
to his Lady, and by all conjectures, this is a disguised
whore; I will try if I can search this Mine.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Thou art a pretty Boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: And you a brave man: now I am out of your debt.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Nay prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p: I am in haste sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: By the faith of a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
Take heed what you say, you have taken a strange
Oath.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
I have not seen a youth that hath pleased me
better, I would thou couldst like me, so far as to leave
thy Lady and wait on me, I would maintain thee in
the bravest Clothes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Though you took them up on trust, or bought
them at the brokers.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Or any way: then thy employments should
be so neat and cleanly, thou shouldst not touch
a pair of Pantofles in a Month, and thy lodging -

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p: Should be in a brothel.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: No, but in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
That may be the circle of a Bawdy house, or
worse.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I mean thou shouldest lie with me.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
Lie with you? I had rather lie with my Ladies
Monkey; it was never a good World since our French
Lords learned of the Neopolitans; to make their Pages
their Bedfellows, doth more hurt to the Suburb
Ladies than twenty dead Vacations; It is Supper
time sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
I thought so, I know by that it is a Woman,
for because peradventure she hath made trial of the
Monkey, she prefers him before me, as one unknown;
well these are standing Creatures, and have strange
desires; And men must use strange means to quench
strange fires.

div2.stage: Enter Montague, alone, in meane habit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Now Montague, who discerns thy spirit now?
Thy breeding or thy blood? here is a poor cloud
Eclipseth all thy splendour; who can read
In thy pale face, dead eye, or lenten shute,
The liberty thy ever-giving hand
Hath bought for others, manacling itself
In gyves of parchment indissoluble?
The greatest hearted man supplied with means,
Nobility of birth and gentlest parts,
I though the right hand of his Sovereign,
If virtue quit her seat in his high soul,
Glitters but like a Palace set on fire,
Whose glory whilst it shines, but ruins him,
And his bright show each hour to ashes tending
Shall at the last be raked up like a sparkle,
Unless men's lives and fortunes feed the flame.
Not for my own wants though blame I my Stars,
But suffering others to cast love on me,
When I can neither take nor thankful be.
My Ladies woman, fair and virtuous
Young as the present month, solicits me
For love and marriage now being nothing worth -

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
O Master, I have sought you a long hour,
Good faith, I never joyed out of your fight;
For Gods sake sir be merry, or else bear
The Buffets of your fortunes with more scorn;
Do but begin to rail, teach me the way,
And I will sit down and help your anger forth:
I have known you wear a suit full worth a Lordship,
Give to a man whose need never frighted you
From calling of him friend, five hundred Crowns
Ere sleep had left your senses to consider
Your own important present uses; yet
Since I have seen you with a trencher wait,
Void of all scorn, therefore I will wait on you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Would God thou wert less honest.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Would to God you were less worthy: I am even
wee sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Is not thy Master strangely fallen, when thou
Servest for no wages, but for charity?
Thou dost surcharge me with thy plenteous love:
The goodness of thy virtue shown to me,
More opens still my disability
To quit thy pains: Credit me loving boy,
A free and honest nature may be oppressed,
Tired with courtesies from a liberal spirit,
When they exceed his means of gratitude.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
But it is a due in him that to that end
Extends his love or duty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Little world
Of virtue, why dost love and follow me?

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
I will follow you through all Countries,
I will run (fast as I can) by your horse side,
I will hold your stirrup when you do alight,
And without grudging wait till you return:
I will quit offered means, and expose myself
To cold and hunger still to be with you;
Fearless I will travel through a wilderness,
And when you are weary, I will lay me down
That in my bosom you may rest your head,
Where whilst you sleep, I will watch that no wild beast
Shall hurt or trouble you: and thus we will breed a story
To make every hearer weep,
When they discourse our fortunes and our loves.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
O what a scoff might men of Worms make,
If they did know this boy? but my desire
Is that thou wouldst not (as thou usest still
When like a servant I among servants sit)
Wait on my Trencher, fill my cups with wine:
Why shouldst thou do this boy? prithee consider,
I am not what I was.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Cursed be the day when I forget that Montague
was my Lord, or not remember him my Master still.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Rather curse me, with whom thy youth hath spent
So many hours, and yet untaught to live
By any worldly quality.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Indeed you never taught me how to handle Cards
To cheat and cozen men with oaths and lies;
Those are the worldly qualities to live:
Some of our Scarlet Gallants teach their boys
These worldly qualities.
Since stumbling fortune then leaves virtue thus
Let me leave fortune, ere be vicious.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O lad, thy love will kill me.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
In truth, I think in conscience I shall die for you:
Good Master weep not, do you want aught sir?
Will you have any money? here is some Silver;
And here is a little Gold, it will serve to play,
And put more troublesome thoughts out of your mind:
I pray sir take it, I will get more with singing.
And then I will bring it you; my Lady gave it me,
And - it was not covetousness,
But I forgot to tell you sooner of it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Alas boy, thou art not bound to tell it me,
And less to give it, buy thee Scarfs and Garters,
And when I have money, I will give thee a Sword:
Nature made thee a beauteous Cabinet
To lock up all the goodness of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
I have lost my voice with the very sight of this
Gentlewoman: good sir steal away, you were wont to
be a curious avoider of women's company.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Why boy, thou darest trust me any where, darest
thou not?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
I had rather trust you by a roaring Lion, than a
ravening woman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why boy.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why truly she devours more man's flesh -

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Aye, But she roars not boy.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
No sir, why she is never silent but when her mouth
is full.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Monsieur Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: My sweet fellow, since you please to call me so.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Ah my conscience she would be pleased well enough
to call you bedfellow: O Master, do not hold
her by the hand so: a woman is a lime-bush, that catcheth
all she toucheth.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
I do most dangerously suspect this boy to be a
wench; art thou not one? come hither, let me feel
thee.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Why dost thou pull off thy glove?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, to feel whether you be a boy, or no.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
Fie boy, go to, I will not look your head, nor
comb your locks any more, if you talk thus.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why, I will sing to you no more then.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
Fie upon it, how sad you are? a young Gentleman
that was the very Sun of France.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: But I am in the eclipse now.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
Suffer himself to be over-run with a Lethargy
of melancholy and discontent! rouse up thy spirit,
man, and shake it off:
A Noble soul is like a ship at Sea,
That sleeps at Anchor when the Ocean is calm;
But when she rages, and the wind blows high,
He cuts his way with skill and Majesty.
I would turn a fool, or Poet, or anything, or marry, to
make you merry; prithee let us walk: good Veramour
leave thy Master and me, I have earnest business with
him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Pray do you leave my Master, and me; we were
very merry before you came, he does not covet women's
company.
What have you to do with him? come sir will you go?
And I will sing to you again:
I'faith his mind is stronger than to credit women's vows,
and too pure to be capable of their loves.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
The boy is jealous; sweet lad leave us; my Lady
called for you I swear: that is a good child, there is a
piece of Gold for thee, go buy a Feather.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
There is two pieces for you, do you go and buy
one, or what you will, or nothing so you go. Nay
then I see you would have me go sir; why, i'faith I will;
now I perceive you love her better then you do me; but
God bless you whatever you do, or intend; I know
you are a very honest man.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
Still shall I woe thee, whilst thy ears reply
I cannot, or I will not marry thee?
Why hast thou drawn the blood out of my cheeks,
And given a quicker motion to my heart?
O thou hast bred a fever in my veins
Called love, which no Physician can cure;
Have mercy on a maid whose simple youth -

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
How your example fairest teacheth me
A ceremonious Idolatry!
By all the joy of love I love thee better
Than I or any man can tell another;
And will express the mercy which thou cravest,
I will forbear to marry thee: consider
Thou art natures heir in feature, and thy parents
In fair inheritances; rise with these thoughts,
And look on me; but with a woman's eye,
A decayed fellow, void of means and spirit.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Of spirit?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Yes, could I tamely live,
Forget my fathers blood, wait and make legs,
Stain my best breeches, with the servile drops
That fall from others draughts:

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p:
This vizard wherewith thou wouldst hide thy spirit
Is perspective, to show it plainlier.
This under-value of thy life is but
Because I should not buy thee; what more speaks
Greatness of man, then valiant patience,
That shrinks not under his fates strongest strokes?
These Roman deaths, as falling on a Sword,
Opening of veins, with poison quenching thirst,
(Which we erroneously do style the deeds
Of the heroic and magnanimous man)
Was dead-eyed cowardice, and white cheek fear,
Who doubting tyranny, and fainting under
Fortunes false Lottery, desperately run
To death for dread of death; that soul is most stout,
That bearing all mischance, dares last it out;
Will you perform your word, and marry me,
When I shall call you to it?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Who is this alights here?

sp.speaker: Long,
sp.p:
With leave fair creature, are you the Lady Mistress
of the house?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Her servant sir.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
I pray then favour me, to inform your Lady, and
Duke Orleans wife,
A business of import awaits them here,
And craves for speedy answer.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Are you in post sir?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
No, I am in Satin Lady; I would you would be
in post.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: I will return, Sweet.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Honest friend, do you belong to the house?
I pray be covered.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes Sir; I do.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Ha, dreamest thou Longaville? sure it is not he: sir
I should know you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
So should I you, but that I am ashamed.
But though thou knowest me, prithee Longaville,
Mock not my poverty, pray remember yourself;
Shows it not strangely for thy clothes to stand
Without a hat to mine? mock me no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
The -- embroider me all over sir,
If ever I began to mock you yet.
The - on me, why should I wear Velvet
And Silver Lace, - I will tear it off.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why mad-man?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Put on my Hat? yes, when I am hanged I will:
- I could break my head
For holding eyes that knew not you at first:
But time and fortune run your courses with him,
He will laugh and storm you, when you show most hate.

div2.stage: Enter Lamira, Orleans Lady, Laverdine, La Poope, Malycorne, Veramour, Charlot:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You are a fair Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: do you mock me Lady?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Your business sir, I mean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Regard yourself good Monsieur Longueville.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
You are too negligent of yourself and place,
Cover your head sweet Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Mistake me not fair Ladies,
It is not to you, nor you, that I stand bare.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Nay sweet dear Monsieur, let it not be to us then.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: - a complement.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
And - of manners.
Pray hide your head, your gallants use to do it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
And you your foreheads, why you needful accessory rascals,
That cannot live without your mutual knaveries,
More than a Bawd, a Pander, or a Whore
From one another; how dare you suspect
That I stand bare to you? what make you here?
Shift your house Lady of them, for I know them,
They come to steal Napkins, and your Spoons;
Look to your Silver-bodkin, (Gentlewoman)
It is a dead utensil, and Page beware your pockets;
My reverence is unto this man, my master,
Whom you with protestations, and oaths
As high as Heaven, as deep as hell, which would
Deceive the wisest man of honest nature,
Have cozened and abused; but I may meet you,
And beat you one with the other.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Peace, no more.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Not a word sir.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I am something thick of hearing; what said he?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I hear him, but regard him not.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, I am never angry fasting.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
My love keeps back my duty, noblest Lady;
If husband or brother merit love from you,
Prevent their dangers, this hour brings to trial
Their hereto sleeping hates; by this time each
Within a yard is of the others heart,
And met to prove their causes and their spirits
With their impartial Swords points; haste and save,
Or never meet them more but at the grave.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
O my distracted heart, that my wracked honour
Should for a brothers, or a husbands life, through thy
undoing die.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Amiens engaged; if he miscarry all my hopes and joys,
I now confess it loudly, are undone:
Caroche, and haste, one minute may betray
A life more worth than all time can repay.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Hump: Monsieur Laverdine pursues this boy extremely.
Captain what will you do?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
Anything but follow to this Sea-service; I am
a Sea-captain you know, and to offer to part them, without
we could do it like water-men with long staves, a
quarter of a mile off, might be dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Why then let us retire and pray for them, I am resolved
to stop your intent; abused more than we have
been we cannot be, without they fall to flat beating of us.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: And that were unkindly done i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
- but you are the troublesomest Ass that ever I
met with; retire, you smell like a woman's chamber, that is
newly up, before she have pinched her vapours in with her
clothes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
I will haunt thee like thy Grandam's ghost, thou
shalt never rest for me.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
Well, I perceive it is vain to conceal a secret from
you: believe it sir, indeed I am a woman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Why la; I knew it, this Prophetical tongue of
mine never failed me; my mother was half a witch, never
anything that she forespake, but came to pass: a
woman? how happy am I? now we may lawfully come
together without fear of hanging; Sweet wench, be
gracious, in honourable sort I woe, no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p: Faith the truth is I have loved you long.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: See, see.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p: But durst not open it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: - I think so.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
But briefly, when you bring it to the test, if there
be not one Gentleman in this house, will challenge more
interest in me, then you can, I am at your disposure.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
O Fortunatus, I envy thee not
For cap, or pouch, this day I will prove my Fortune,
In which your Lady doth elect her husband,
Who will be Amiens, it will save my wedding dinner,
Povera, La-poop and Malicorne: if all fail,
I will turn Citizen, a beauteous wife
Is the horn-book to the richest Tradesman's life.

div2.stage: Enter Duboys, Orleans, Longueville, Amiens, two Lacques, a Page wish two Pistols.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
Here is a good even piece of ground my Lords:
Will you fix here?

sp.speaker: Orl.
Dub.
sp.p: On the ropes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Upon a line.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
So all our Country Duels are carried, like a firework
on a thread.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Go now stay with the horses, and do you hear
Upon your lives, till some of us come to you,
Dare not to look this way.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
Except you see strangers or others that by chance
or purpose are like to interrupt us,

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then give warning.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Who takes a Sword? the advantage is so small,
As he that doubts hath the free leave to choose.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Come give me any, and search me; it is not
The ground, weapon, or seconds that can make
Odds in those fatal trials: but the cause.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
Most true, and but it is no time to wish
When men are come to do, I would desire
The cause betwixt us were other than it is;
But where the right is, there prevail our Swords.
And if my sister have outlived her honour,
I do not pray I may outlive her shame.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Your sister Amiens, is a whore, at once.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
You oft have spoke that sense to me before,
But never in this language Orleance;
And when you spoke it fair, and first, I told you
That it was possible you might be abused:
But now, since you forget your manners, you shall find,
If I transgress my custom, you do lie,
And are a villain, which I had rather yet
My Sword had proved, than I been forced to speak:
Nay give us leave, and since you stand so haughtily
And highly on your cause, let you and I,
Without engaging these two Gentlemen, singly determine it.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, you will pardon us,

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
I trust your Lordships may not do us that
affront.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
We kiss your Lordships hand, and come to serve
you here with Swords.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: My Lord, we understand ourselves.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
We have had the honour to be called unto the
business, and we must not now quit it on terms.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Not terms of reason?

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No, no reason for the quitting of our calling.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: True if I be called to it I must ask no reason.

div2.stage: A noise within, crying down with their Swords.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Nor hear none neither, which is less:
It is a favour if my throat be cut,
Your Lordship does me; which I never can,
Nor must have hope how to requite: what noise,
What cry is that my Lord upon your guard?
Some treachery is a foot.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
O here they are:
My Lord (dear Lady help me) help me all;
I have so woeful interest in both,
I know not which to fear for most: and yet
I must prefer my Lord. Dear brother,
You are too understanding, and too Noble
To be offended, when I know my duty,
Though scarce my tears will let me so to do it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Out loathed strumpet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
O my dearest Lord,
If words could on me cast the name of whore,
I then were worthy to be loathed; but know,
Your unkindness cannot make me wicked;
And therefore should less use that power upon me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Was this your art to have these actors come,
To make this interlude? withdraw, cold man,
And if thy spirit be not frozen up,
Give me one stroke yet at thee for my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
Thou shalt have strokes, and strokes, thou glorious man,
Till thou breathest thinner air than that thou talkest.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: My Lord Count Amiens.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Princely husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Whore.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
You wrong her impudent Lord; O that I had the bulk
Of those dull men; look how they stand, and no man
Will revenge an innocent Lady.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: You hinder it Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
I would hinder you; is there none else to kill
him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Kill him Madam? have you learned that bad Language? O repent,
And be the motive, rather both kill me.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Then die my infamy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Hold bloody man.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Art thou their Basilisk?

sp.speaker: Mont:
sp.p:
To strike thee dead, but that thy fate deserves
some weightier hand.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
O here is a plot; you bring your champions with
you; the adulteress with the adulterer: Out howling -

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Are you her Graces countenance Lady, the
receiver to the poor vicious couple.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Sweet my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Sweet rascal, didst not thou tell me, false fellow,
This Montague, here was murdered?

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
I did so; but he was falser, and a worthless Lord,
Like thy foul self, that would have had it so.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Orleance it is true, and shall be proved upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Thy malice Duke, and this thy wicked nature,
are all as visible as thou; but I borne to contemn thy
injuries, do know, that though thy greatness may corrupt
a Jury, and make a Judge afraid, and carry out a
world of devils with thy title: yet thou art not quiet
at home, thou bearest about thee that, that doth charge
thee, and condemn thee too. The thing that grieves me
more, and doth indeed displease me, is, to think that
so much baseness stands here to have encountered so
much honour: Pardon me my Lord what late my passion
spake, when you provoked my innocence.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Yes do, O flattery becomes him better than the
suit he wears; give him a new one Amiens.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
Orleance, it is here no time nor place, to jest or rail
Poorly with you, but I will find a time to
Whisper you forth to this or some fit place,
As shall not hold a second interruption.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I hope your Lordships honour, and your life
Are destined unto higher hazards; this is of
A meaner arm.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: Yes faith, or none.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
He is not fit to fall by an honest Sword,
A Prince and lie!

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
And slander, and hire men
To publish the false rumours he hath made.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: And stick them on his friends, and innocents.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p:
And practice against their lives after their
fames.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
In men that are the matter of all lewdness,
Bawds, thieves, and cheaters, it were monstrous.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: But in a man of blood, how more conspicuous?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: They do slander him.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Hang them, a pair of railing hang-bys.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
How? stand Orleance; stay, give me my Pistols boy,
Hinder me not, by -
I will kill him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O stay his fury,

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Longueville, my friend.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
Not for myself, my Lord, but for mankind,
And all that have an interest to virtue,
Or title unto innocence.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Why hear me.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: For justice sake.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That cannot be.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
To punish his wives, your honour, and my Lords
wrongs here, whom I must ever call so; for your loves
I will swear, I will sacrifice -

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
Longaville, I did not think you a murtherer
before.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: I care not what you thought me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
By - If thou attempt
His life, thy own is forfeit.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Foolish frantic man, the murder will be of us,
not him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
We could have killed him, but we would not take
The justice out of fates. -
Singe but a hair of him, thou diest.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: No matter, shoot.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Villain.

sp.speaker: Dub.
sp.p: My Lord, your sister is slain.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: O hapless and most wretched chance.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Standest thou looking upon the mischief thou hast made
Thou Godless man, feeding thy blood-shot eyes
With the red spectacle, and art not turned to stone
With horror? hence and take the wings of thy black
Infamy, to carry thee beyond the shoot of looks,
Or sound of curses, which will pursue thee still:
Thou hast out-fled all but thy guilt.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
O wish it off again, for I am cracked
Under the burden, and my heart will break.
How heavy guilt is, when men come to feel
If you could know the mountain I sustain
With horror, you would each take off your part,
And more, to ease me: I cannot stand,
Forgive where I have wronged I pray.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Look to him Montague.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
My Lords and Gentlemen, the Lady is well but for fear,
Unless that have shot her;
I have the worst of it, that needs would venture
Upon a trick had like to have cost my guts:
Look to her, she will be well, it was but Powder
I charged with, thinking that a guilty man
Would have been frighted sooner; but I am glad
He has come at last.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How is Byancha? well?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Lives she? see sister, doth she breath?

sp.speaker: Lady.
Dub.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, he is well.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ha my husband.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
I cannot speak whether my joy or shame
Be greater, but I thank the Heavens for both.
O look not black upon me, all my friends,
To whom I will be reconciled, or grow unto
This earth, till I have wept a trench
That shall be great enough to be my grave,
And I will think them too most manly tears,
If they do move your pities: it is true,
Man should do nothing that he should repent;
But if he have, and say that he is sorry,
It is a worse fault if he be not truly.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
My Lord, such sorrow cannot be suspected:
Here take your honoured wife, and join your hands.
- she hath married you again:
And Gentlemen, I do invite you all,
This night to take my house, where on the morrow,
To heighten more the reconciling feast,
I will make myself a husband and a guest.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Well now I am sure you are mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I am sure I am glad
I have one to own then; you will find me honest
As these days go, enough; poor without question,
Which beggars hold a virtue; give me meat, and I
Shall do my work, else knock my shoes off,
And turn me out again.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: You are a merry fellow.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: I have no great cause.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Yes thy love to me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: That is as we make our game.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Why you repent then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Faith no worse than I am I cannot be;
Much better I expect not: I shall love you,
And when you bid me go to bed, obey,
Lie still or move, as you shall minister,
Keep a four-nobles Nag, and a black
Merling, learn to love Ale, and play at two-hand Irish,
And there is then all I aim at.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Nay sweet fellow, I will make it something better.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
If you do you will make me worse:
Now I am poor, and willing to do well,
Hold me in that course, of all the Kings creatures,
I hate his coin, keep me from that, and save me;
For if you chance out of your housewifery
To leave a hundred pound or two, bestow it
In Plum-broth ere I know it, else I take it;
Seek out a hundred men that want this money,
Share it among them they will, cry noble Montague,
And so I stand again at livery.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
You have pretty fancies sir, but married once,
This charity will fall home to yourself.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I would it would, I am afraid my looseness
Is yet scarce stopped, though it have naught to work on
But the mere air of what I have had.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Pretty.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
I wonder sweet heart why you will marry me,
I can see nothing in myself deserves it,
Unless the handsome wearing of a band,
For that is my stock now, or a pair of garters,
Necessity will not let me loose.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
I see sir a great deal more, a handsome man, a husband
To make a right good woman truly happy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Lord, where are my eyes? either you are foolish
As wenches once a year are, or far worse,
Extremely virtuous, can you love a poor man
That relies on cold meat and cast stockings,
One only suit to his back, which now is mewing?
But what will be the next coat will pose Tristram.
If I should levy from my friends a fortune:
I could not raise ten groats to pay the Priest now.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
I will do that duty; it is not means nor money
Makes me pursue your love; were your mind bankrupt,
I would never love you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Peace wench, here is my Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Nay never shrink in the wetting, for my presence;
do ye find her willing Montague?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Willing Madam?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
How dainty you make of it, do not I know
You two love one another?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Certain Madam, I think ye have revelations of these matters:
Your Ladyship cannot tell me when I kissed her.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: But she can, sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
Lam.
sp.p: Thou art wanton.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
God knows I need not, yet I would be lusty:
But - my provender scarce pricks me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
It shall be mended Montague, I am glad you are
grown so merry.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: So am I too Madam.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You two will make a pretty handsome consort.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes Madam, if my fiddle fail me not.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Your Fiddle? why your Fiddle? I warrant thou
meanest madly:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Can you blame me? alas I am in love.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It is very well sir.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How long have you been thus?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How thus in love?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You are very quick sir: no, I mean thus pleasant.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: - Ever since I was poor.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: A little wealth would change you then.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Yes Lady into another suit, but never more
Into another man: I will bar that mainly,
The wealth I get henceforward shall be charmed
For ever hurting me, I will spend it fasting:
As I live noble Lady there is nothing
I have found directly cures the melancholy,
But want and wedlock; when I had store of money
I simpered sometime, and spoke wondrous wise,
But never laughed out-right; now I am empty
My heart sounds like a bell, and strikes at both sides.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You are finely tempered Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Pardon Lady, if any way my free mirth have offended,
It was meant to please you: if it prove too saucy,
Give it a frown, and I am ever silenced.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
I like it passing well; pray follow it:
This is my day of choice, and shall be yours too,
It were pity to delay ye: call to the Steward,
And tell him it is my pleasure he should give you
five hundred Crowns: make yourself handsome Montague,
Let none wear better clothes, it is for my credit;
But pray be merry still.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
If I be not, and make a fool of twice as many hundreds,
Clap me in Canvas Lady.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
I am strangely glad, I have found the mystery
Of this disguised boy out: I ever trusted
It was a woman, and how happily
I have found it so; and for myself, I am sure
One that would offer me a thousand pound now
(And that is a pretty sum to make one stagger)
In ready Gold for this concealment, could not
Buy my hope of her, she is a dainty wench,
And such a one I find I want extremely
To bring me into credit: beauty does it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Say we should all meech here, and stay the feast,
now what can the worst be? we have played the knaves,
that is without question.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
True, and as I take it this is the first truth
We told these ten years, and for anything
I know may be the last: but grant we are knaves,
Both base and beastly knaves -

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Say so then.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
And likewise let it be considered, we have wronged
And most maliciously, this Gentlewoman,
We cast to stay with, what must we expect now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Aye there is the point, we would expect good eating.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I know we would, but we may find good beating.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
You say true Gentlemen, and by -
Though I love meat as well as any man,
I care not what he be, if a eat in Gods name;
Such crab-sauce to my meat will turn my palate.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
There is all the hazard, for the frozen Montague
Has now got spring again, and warmth in him,
And without doubt dares beat us terribly.
For not to mint the matter, we are cowards,
And have and shall be beaten when men please
To call us into cudgelling.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I feel we are very prone that way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: The sons of Adam.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
Now here then rests the state of the question?
Whether we yield our bodies for a dinner
To a sound dog-whip, for I promise ye
If men be given to correction,
We can expect no less, or quietly
Take a hard Egg or two, and ten mile hence
Bait in a ditch, this we may do securely;
For to stay here about will be all one,
If once our moral mischiefs come in memory.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
But pray ye hear me, is not this the day
The Virgin Lady doth elect her husband?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: The dinner is to that end.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Very well then, say we all stay, and say we all
scape this whipping, and be well entertained, and one
of us carry the Lady.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
It is a seemly saying, I must confess, but if we stay, how fitly
We may apply it to ourselves (in the end)
Will ask a Christian fear; I cannot see
If I say true, what special ornaments
Of art or nature, lay aside our lying
Whoring and drinking, which are no great virtues,
We are endued withal to win this Lady.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Yet women go not by the best parts ever; that I
have found directly.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Why should we fear then? they choose men
As they feed; some times they settle
Upon a white-broth face, a sweet smooth gallant,
And him they make an end of in a night;
Sometimes a Goose, sometimes, a grosser meat,
A rump of beef will serve them at some season,
And fill their bellies too: though without doubt
They are great devourers: stock fish is a dish,
If it be well dressed, for the toughness' sake
Will make the proudest of them long and leap for it.
They will run mad for a pudding ere they will starve,

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
For my own part I care not, come what can come,
If I be whipped, why so be it; if cudgeled,
I hope I shall out live it, I am sure
It is not the hundredth time I have been served so,
And yet I thank God I am here.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Here is resolution.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
A little patience, and a rotten Apple
Cures twenty worse diseases; what say you sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Marry I say sir, if I had been acquainted
With lamming in my youth, as you have been
With whipping, and such benefits of nature,
I should do better: as I am, I will venture,
And if it be my luck to have the Lady,
I will use my fortune modestly; if beaten
You shall not hear a word, one I am sure of,
And if the worst fall she shall be my physic.
Let us go then, and a merry wind be with us,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Captain your shoes are old, pray put them off,
And let one fling them after us; be bold sirs,
And howsoever our fortune falls, let us bear
An equal burden; if there be an odd lash,
We will part it afterwards.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: I am armed at all points.

div2.stage: Enter foure serving in a Banquet.

sp.p: Then my Lady will have a bedfellow tonight.

So she says, heaven what a dainty armful shall he
enjoy that has the launching of her, what a fight she will make.

Aye marry boys, there will be sport indeed, there will
be grappling, she has a murderer lies in her prow,
I am afraid will fright his main mast Robin.

Who dost thou think shall have her of thy conscience,
thou art a wise man.

If she go the old way, the way of lot, the longest cut
sweeps all without question?

She has lost a friend of me else; what think ye
of the Courtier.

Hang him hedgehog, he has nothing in him but a
piece of Euphues, and twenty dozen of twelve penny
riband all about him, he is but one Peddlers shop of gloves
and garters, pickteeth and pomander.

The Courtier! marry God bless her Steven, she is
not mad yet, she knows that trindle-tail too well, he is
crest fallen, and pin-buttocked, with leaping Laundresses.

The Merchant sure she will not be so base to
have him.
I hope so Robin, he will sell us all to the Moors to make mummy; nor the Captain.
Who Potgun, that is a sweet youth indeed, will he stay think ye?

Yes, without question, and have half dined too ere
the grace be done; he is good for nothing in the world
but eating, lying and sleeping; what other men devour
in drink, he takes in Pottage, they say has been at
Sea, a Herring fishing, for without doubt he dares not
hail an Eel-boat, in the way of War.

I think so, they would beat him off with
Butter.

When he brings in a prize, unless it be Cockles,
or Callis sand to scour with, I will renounce my five
mark a year, and all the hidden art I have in carving, to
teach young Birds to whistle Walsingham; leave him
to the lime boats; now, what think you of the brave
Amiens?
That is a thought indeed.

Aye marry there is a person fit to feed upon a dish so
dainty, and he will do it I warrant him in the nick-boys, has
a body world without end.

And such a one my Lady will make no little off;
but is not Montague married today?

Yes faith, honest Montague must have his bout
too.

He is as good a lad as ever turned a trencher; must
we leave him?

He is too good for us Steven, I will give him health
to his good luck tonight in the old Beaker, and it shall be
sack too.

I must have a Garter; and boys I have bespoke, a
a Posset, somebody shall give me thanks for it, it has a few
toys in it will raise commotions in a bed lad.
Away; my Lady.

div2.stage: Enter Orleance, and his Lady arme in arme, Amiens, Lamira, Charlote, like a Bride, Montague brave, Laverdine, Longavile Dubois, Mallycorn, La-Poope.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Stir yourselves noble Lords and Gentlemen,
You know your places; many royal welcomes
I give your grace; how lovely shows this change?
My house is honoured in this reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Thus Madam must you do, my Lady now shall see
You made a Woman;
And give you some short lessons for your voyage.
Take her instructions Lady, she knows much.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: This becomes you sir.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: My Lord must have his will.

sp.speaker: Orl.
Ami.
sp.p: I will pledge you.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And with my heart.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: With all my love I take it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Noble Lords I am proud ye have done this day,
so much content, and me such estimation that this hour
(In this poor rouse) shall be a league for ever,
For so I know ye mean it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: I do Lady.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: And I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ye have done a work of honour.

sp.speaker: Ami.
Orl.
sp.p:
Pray sit down sir, I know the Lady of the feast
expects not this day so much old custom.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Sit down Mountague; nay never blush for the
matter.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
Noble Madam, I have two reasons against it, and
I dare not; duty to you first, as you are my Lady, and I
your poorest servant; next the custom of this day's
ceremony.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: As you are my servant, I may command you then.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: To my life Lady.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Sit down, and here, I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
Sit down man, never refuse so fair a Ladies
offer.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
It is your pleasure Madam, not my pride,
And I obey; I will pledge ye now my Lord, Monsieur
Longavile.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
This to my Lady, and her fair choice today,
and happiness.

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.p:
It is a fair health, I will pledge you though I
sink for it.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Montague you are too modest; come I will add
a little more wine to ye, it will make you merry, this to
the good I wish. -

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Honoured Lady, I shall forget myself with
this great bounty.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: You shall not sir; give him some Vine.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
By heaven you are a worthy woman, and that
Man is blessed can come near such a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Such a blessing wet weather washes.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: At all, I will not go a lip less my Lord.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: It is well cast sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
If Montague get more Wine, we are like to hear
of it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I do not like that sitting there.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, methinks he looks like a Judge.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
Now have I a kind a grudging of a beating on
me, I fear my hot fit.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Drink apace, there is nothing allays a cudgel
like it.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
Montague, now I will put my choice to you; who
do you hold in all this honoured company a husband
fit to enjoy thy Lady? speak directly.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Shall I speak Madam?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Montague, you shall.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Then as I have a soul I will speak my conscience,
Give me more wine, in vino veritas,
Here is to myself, and Montague have a care.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Speak to the cause.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; first I will begin to thee.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Have at us,

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Now for a Psalm of mercy.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
You good Monsieur, you that belie the noble
Name of Courtier, and think your claim good here,
hold up your hand; your Worship is indicted here, for
a vain glorious fool.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Good, O sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
For one whose wit
Lies in a ten pound waistcoat, yet not warm;
Ye have travelled like a Fiddler to make faces,
And brought home nothing but a case of tooth-picks.
You would be married, and no less than Ladies,
And of the best sort can serve you; thou silk worm
What hast thou in thee to deserve this woman?
Name but the poorest piece of man, good manners,
There is nothing sound about thee, faith thou hast none,
It lies pawned at thy silk man's, for so much lace;
Thy credit which is worse cannot redeem it,
Thy clothes are all the soul thou hast, for so
Thou savest them handsome for the next great tilting
Let who will take the the other, thou wert never christened
Upon my conscience (but in barbers water)
Thou art never out of the basin, thou art rotten,
And if thou darest tell truth, thou wilt confess it;
- thy skin
Looks of a Chestnut colour, greased with Amber
All women that on earth do dwell thou lovest,
Yet none that understand love thee again,
But those that love the Spittle, get thee home
Poor painted butter fly, thy summers past;
Go sweat and eat dry Mutton, thou mayst live
To do so well yet; a bruised Chamber Maid
May fall upon thee, and advance thy follies.
You have your sentence; now it follows Captain,
I treat of you.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Pray God I may deserve it.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: Beshrew my heart he speaks, plain.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: That is plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You are a rascal Captain.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: A fine calling.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: A water coward.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: He would make a pretty stuff.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Nay I speak freely Madam.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Here is none ties you.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Why shouldst thou dare come hither with a thought
To find a wife here fit for thee? are all
Thy single money whores that fed on Carrots,
And filled the high grass with familiars
Fallen off to footmen? prithee tell me truly,
For now I know thou darest not lie, couldst thou not
Wish thyself beaten well with all thy heart now,
And out of pain? say that I broke a rib,
Or cut thy nose off, wert not merciful for this ambition?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Do your pleasure sir, beggars must not be choosers.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p: He longs for beating.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p:
But that I have nobler thoughts possess my soul,
Than such brown biscuit, such a piece of dog-fish,
Such a most mangy Mackrel eater as thou art
That dares do nothing that belongs to the Sea,
But spew, and catch rats, and fear men of war,
Though thou hast nothing in the world to lose
Aboard thee, but one piece of beef, one Musket
Without a cock for peace sake, and a pitch barrel,
I will tell thee if my time were not more precious
Than thus to lose it, I would rattle thee,
It may be beat thee, and thy pure fellow,
The Merchant there of Catskins, till my words,
Or blows, or both, made ye two branded wretches
To all the world hereafter; you would fain to
Venture your bills of lading for this Lady;
What would you give now for her? some five frail
Of rotten Figs good, Godson, would you not sir?
Or a Parrot that speaks high Dutch? can all thou ever sawest
Of thine own fraughts from Sea, or cozenage
(At which thou art as expert as the devil)
Nay sell thy soul for wealth to, as thou wilt do,
Forfeit thy friends, and raise a mint of Money,
Make thee dream all these double could procure
A kiss from this good Lady? canst thou hope
She would lie with such a nook of hell as thou art,
And hatch young Merchant-furies? O ye dog-bolts
That fear no God but Dunkirks, I shall see you
Serve in a lousy Lime boat, ere I die,
For mouldy cheese and butter Billingsgate
Would not endure, or bring in rotten Pippins
To cure blue eyes, and swear they came from China.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Vex them no more, alas they shake:

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Down quickly on your marrow bones and
thank this Lady.
I would not leave you thus else, there are blankets,
And such delights for such knaves; but fear still;
It will be revenge enough, to keep you waking.
Ye have no mind of Marriage, have ye?

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p: Surely no great mind now.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Nor you.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Nor I, I take it.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Two eager suitors.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Troth it is wondrous hot, God bless us from him

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
You have told me Montague
Who are not fit to have me, let me know
The man you would point out for me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
There he sits; my Lord of Amiens, Madam, is
my choice, he is noble every way, and worthy a wife
with all the dowries of -

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you speak sir out of your friendship to me?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Yes, my Lord, and out of truth, for I could never
flatter.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
I would not say how much I owe you for it,
For that were but a promise, but I will thank ye,
As now I find you, in despite of fortune,
A fair and noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
My Lords I must confess the choice this man hath made
Is every way a great one, if not too great,
And no way to be slighted: yet because
We love to have our own eyes, sometimes now
Give me a little liberty to see,
How I could fit myself, if I were put to it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Madam we must.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: Are ye all agreed?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We be?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
Then as I am a maid, I shall choose here.
Montague, I must have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Why Madam I have learnt to suffer more
than you can (out of pity) mock me with this way
especially.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
Thou thinkst I jest now;
But by the love I bear thee, I will have thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
If you could be so weak, to love a fallen man,
He must deserve more than I ever can,
Or ever shall (deer Lady;) look but this way
Upon that Lord and you will tell me then
Your eyes are no true choosers of good men.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Do you love him truly?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p:
Yes my Lord, I will obey him truly, for I will
marry him, and justly think he that has so well served
me with his obedience being borne to greatness,
must use me nobly of necessity when I shall serve him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
It were a deep sin to cross ye, noble Montague,
I wish ye all content, and am as happy
In my friends good as it were merely mine.

sp.speaker: Mont.
Cha.
sp.p:
I will end all, I wooed you for my Lady, and
now give up my title, alas poor wench, my aims are
lower far.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: How is this sweet heart?

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
Sweet heart it is so, the drift was mine to hide
My purpose till it struck home.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p:
Prithee leave wondering, by this kiss I will have
thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Then by this kiss, and this I will ever serve ye.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p:
This Gentleman and I sir must needs hop once
more to follow ye.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: As friends and fellows, never as servants more.

sp.speaker: Long., Dub.
sp.p: You make us happy.

sp.speaker: Orl.
sp.p:
Friend Montague, ye have taught me so much
honour, I have found a fault in myself but thus I will purge
my conscience of it, the late land I took by false play,
from you with as much Contrition, and entireness of
affection to this most happy day again, I render; be
Master of your own, forget my malice, and make me
worthy of your love, Lord Montague.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: You have won me and honour to your name.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p:
Since your Lordship has begun good deeds, we will
follow; good sir forgive us, we are now those men
fear you for goodness sake; those sums of money unjustly
we detain from you, on your pardon shall be restored
again, and we your servants.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
You are very forward sir, it seems you have money,
I pray you lay out, I will pay you or pray for you, as the
Sea works.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
Their penance sir I will undertake, so please ye
To grant me on concealment.

sp.speaker: Long.
sp.p: Right courtier, still a begging.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: What is it sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: In my gift?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Yes sir, in yours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why bring her forth and take her.

sp.speaker: Lami.
sp.p: What wench would he have?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Any wench I think.

div2.stage: Enter Laverdine and Veramour, like a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: This is the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: It is my Page sir.

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p:
No sir, I am a poor disguised Lady?
That like a Page have followed you full long for love god-wot.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: A Lady - Laverdine - yes, yes, it is a Lady.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
It may be so, and yet we have lain together,
But by my troth I never found her, Lady.

sp.speaker: L Orl.
sp.p: Why wore you boys clothes?

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p:
I will tell you Madam,
I took example by two or three plays, that methought
Concerned me.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Why made you not me acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Indeed sir I knew it not myself,
Until this Gentleman opened my dull eyes,
And by persuasion made me see it.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Could his power in words make such a change?

sp.speaker: Uer.
sp.p: Yes, as truly woman as yourself my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Why but hark you, are not you a woman?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: If hands and face make it not evident, you shall see more.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Breeches, breeches, Laverdine.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
It is not enough, women may wear those cases.
Search further Courtier.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: La-p.
sp.p:
O thou freshwater Gudgeon, wouldst thou come
To point of Marriage with an Ignoramus?
Thou shouldst have had her urine to the doctors,
The foolishest Physician could have made plain
The liquid Epicaene; a blind man by the hand
Could have discovered the ring from the stone.
Boy, come, to Sea with me, I will teach thee to climb,
And come down by the rope, nay to eat Rats.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
I shall devour my Master before the prison then,
Sir, I have began my Trade.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Trade? to the City child, a flatcap will become thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p:
Gentlemen I beseech you molest yourselves no further,
For his preferment it is determined.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p:
I am much ashamed, and if my cheek
Gives not satisfaction, break my head.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.p: Your shame is enough sir.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p:
Montague, much joy attend thy marriage Bed;
By thy example of true goodness, envy is exiled,
And to all honest men that truth intend,
I wish good luck, fair fate be still thy friend.
